text: Hi both, please watch this short intro video! Your Career Plan is also pinned to this conversation for easy access. Best of luck!
<@U4VR52RQE> pinned their GSuite Presentation <https://prospela.slack.com/files/U4VR52RQE/F63EV8TGF/prospela_-_career_plan__radhika|Prospela - Career Plan: Radhika.pptm> to this channel.

<@U63ESPNBZ>, we have matched you with <@U60D00VU6> as your mentor. Both please feel free to continue chatting within this group (Note: we are muted and won't be involved from here on out) but if you would prefer you should now be able to set up a Direct Message between just yourselves.
Hi Graham, my name's Radhika :slightly_smiling_face:
Thank you for taking time to be my mentor!

Hi Radhika, lovely to meet you, I'm Graham. I work in Marketing as a brand manager so I manage the day to day activities for TUC biscuits and Cheddars biscuits. I have been in marketing for 6 years now after graduating from University so I will be more than happy to help you on your journey in understanding what/ how you will need to do in order to reach your career goals!
Wow that sounds really cool! My first question has to be, did you always know you wanted to go into Marketing?

That's a really good question, like most people I was very unsure of the route I wanted to take, I began studying Architecture as I had a love for buildings both modern and old! I then was very inspired by a teacher that I had at college who, like I will hopefully do with you, put me onto the right career path and mentored me to begin my business/ marketing career
I also began a logo design business through university which was really interesting but I realised I didn't have the experience needed just yet!
At university did you study for a Marketing degree?
I did, I studied business and marketing and I then majored in marketing
I had a placement at Ferrero chocolate which made me realise this is what I want to do!

Oh wow! Ferrero chocolate must've been amazing to work at! I also am planning on studying Business Management with Marketing, however for the longest time I haven't been that keen on going down the university route only for the fact that I learn better by doing the work rather than being told what to learn, if that makes sense? So I've heard about Degree apprenticeships where you work with a company while studying for a degree in business management, and if not applying for apprenticeships as I believe this is more effective for me and the way I learn. I was just wondering, how valued are apprenticeships in marketing (and maybe advertising) or is it better to have a degree?

It was a great place to work! That's interesting you say that as I am presenting to an apprenticeship scheme on Monday for field sales apprentices, this is where individuals like yourself are given the chance to work as part of the sales team at pladis (where I work)
I think a degree is probably the easiest route but if you are a hard working individual then I think you should consider the apprenticeships too
Where have you been looking at information on the apprenticeship schemes?

Well the degree apprenticeships I found on the BBC website (this is my ideal route) and all other apprenticeships I have been looking at on the official apprenticeship website (not going to uni is what it's called I believe) and have been looking at some on the actual website of the companies I'm interested in
That's good, it's great you are doing the necessary research!
What companies are you interested in?

Definitely the BBC, however these are really competitive as there are only 5 available spaces and I have looked at degree apprenticeships available with Pearson College and there are 3 companies (IBM, Tesco and Kantar) that I would be placed with should I be fortunate to get the opportunity, I have looked at a digital marketing apprenticeship with the FCA. I am still on the search for more but I haven't found the ideal one just yet!
Digital marketing would be brilliant, this is an area that even in the time I have been in marketing has progressed the most.
In terms of future opportunity I would suggest a strong digital background
What is truly involved in digital marketing? I have read a lot about it but I'm still not fully sure what's involved in the day to day work

So my digital background is through managing digital agencies, there is an agency which is called MEC who are part of group M. The biggest growth area for us at Pladis is Facebook and Instagram along with skippable adverts and video on demand, this is more of a live marketing role which can be updated at whatever time of the day which is extremely beneficial for marketers
We manage the content but not the day to day running of the digital pages

What would you say are the most important skills for a career in Marketing? (also, my public speaking skills are the worst! I can hear the nerves in my speech when I'm presenting/speaking in front of a large audience, so how much public speaking is really involved in Marketing?)

Most important skills I think are being a people person, within marketing you are effectively the go to person for the sales, project management, finance, category teams. Is that something you are strong at? Also there is quite a bit of public speaking but don't worry about that, that is a skill that is learnt over time

Yes I guess I would say I'm a people's person and get along with people quite well so that's a relief! I'm kind of torn between going into Marketing or Advertising as I would say one of my strongest skills is skewed towards the creative side, is there any opportunity to combine the two?
That's great. You would be very good at marketing. Marketing and advertising is both covered in a brand management job role so you would cover both
What creative activities do you currently do?

Well, at the moment I'm not involved in much as most of my time this year has gone towards studying A-levels, however I've just finished my first year and all the exams so I would like to get involved in a bit more this summer
That's fair enough, how did the exams go?
I would definitely urge you to begin blogging or vlogging
Which will help with creativity
As good as exams can go I guess! I do have a tumblr page where I post most of my writings (poems, short stories etc) would this count as blogging as it does really help with creativity?
That's good to hear! Keep up the good work! Thats really good then, I would definitely keep that up, do you have a following on that?
Yes, almost over 500+ followers, and I aim to grow this more this summer :slightly_smiling_face:
That is extremely impressive! Why don't you bring that across on to Facebook? Or Instagram? That's where the bloggers make the money and social media influencers
I am thinking of bringing it over to Instagram, but it would require a lot of my time so I'm planning on doing so when my summer holidays start!
Great! You definitely should and you seem like you already have the correct understanding of it all
This will help with your CV if you can say you are influencing people through digital media
I never thought of that! Thank you! What else would you say is important in putting myself at a better advantage when it comes to trying to get my first job in marketing?
Have you ever thought of voluntary work? Through this you can help manage the social media, advertising, websites etc?
Yes I have but I've never found the right one as they're either too far or require you to be 18+
Find a local charity (doesn't have to be well known) and see if they would be willing to let you shadow a worker for a week or 2 weeks.
Any extra experience you can get will help you
Do you have a part time job?
I will do! And I have applied for many places, just haven't heard back yet!
Persistence is key! Just keep at it and you will get what you want
If I do not get the apprenticeship I want and choose not to go down the university route, do you think it's a good idea to study for the CIM qualifications independently?
I would see what they need from you, you may find that a company like the BBC have there own qualifications which may be recognised outside of that organisation
But if you can the CIM qualifications will help a lot
What would you say you enjoy/dislike the most about your job in marketing? and how do I know that it's the right career for me?

So I would say I love the creativity, management of the brands and seeing the results of my work, it's very rewarding! If you have an interest in the creative side, which you are strong at, you are a people person and you have an interest in business then Marketing is the right job for you!
Read marketing weekly too, gives you some great insights
Sounds like an ideal job! What is your typical day like in marketing?

My typical day would consist of 3-4 meetings with other departments these could be discussing the performance of the brand or the live projects that we are currently working on, I would then probably receive a few emails from our sales teams asking for information on the new products or existing, around a launch of a new product we are in contact with sales daily. Other emails would be from the agencies (artwork, digital, media, PR), this could be for sign off on creative work or they may be sharing a good result they have had with an article etc. I would be contacted regularly by the factories which could be daily at new product launch and then also we would be working on presentations. This sounds a lot but it really is manageable
Sounds hectic but does seem like a good career to go into! Also, if I decide on doing a digital marketing apprenticeship but I decide I want to work in another area of marketing, is this possible?
100%, most companies like to rotate employees, this way they are able to create rounded individuals
At Ferrero I moved to another department which gave me an insight into trade marketing

That's very helpful, thank you! I've managed to land an opportunity for work experience with the o2 in marketing however it's just  day event where we learn about marketing and help create a marketing plan. Although it's just a day, would this be a good opportunity to add to my CV when applying for a job or would it not be that relevant as it's only a day event?

I think initially you could probably add this as it would show the employer that you have tried marketing and you like marketing so they wouldn't be wasting there time on someone who may take the role but eventually leave as they do not like it
What are the main challenges of working in Marketing?
Good question!

I am finding at the moment the main challenge is managing expectations, I find the marketing department is the centre of the business and therefore we are given a lot of responsibility and in some cases we are not able to deliver a project on the timings that have been asked of us
We would therefore need to manage the sales team and the directors expectations, this is quite difficult

I think that is probably my biggest fear in working in an industry such as Marketing as you have a huge amount of responsibility and really don't want to mess up. Have you got any tips/advice on how to essentially just be good at your job in Marketing?
Firstly nobody is perfect and mistakes happen so, never be afraid of that, each mistake should not be a disappointment but should be a learning curve.
I would say just make friends, be a go to person, take responsibility and be transparent.  You will then over time gain the trust of your team members and they will see you as reliable
I have an example of this for you

A project I am currently working on is a launch of 6 new products which need to be on the shelf in retailers in September, we have recently come up against a lot of challenges which we are trying to resolve but may delay the products, I have therefore been very transparent with the sales team and the leadership team and made this clear to them. Even though I may not deliver the project on time, they still see me as reliable and trustworthy because they know I am not hiding the issues from them
What is the opportunity for progression like in Marketing? You mentioned that you're a brand manager, how long did it take for you to get to that level?
Before I answer, just want to say that these are all great questions you are asking

So I began my career at ferrero in 2011 as a industrial placement for a year, I then went on to be a graduate placement and an assistant brand manager which got me to 2016, I then took the jump from assistant brand manager to brand manager and also a change of company in 2016

That's really great! Do you wake up everyday and look forward to going into work? I only ask this because whenever I consider a job/career I always ask myself whether I would wake up every day and be happy going into work as I really do want to get a job that I love and have a passion for.
I do, I really love what I do and I have a passion for marketing. Agree, if you aren't in a job you like then you lose interest very quick!
That is a really good way to think about it, have you ever thought about PR, as you like writing and creativity?
You must have worked with a lot of people throughout your years in marketing. what personality do you think is most suited for Marketing?
You would need to be an outgoing, confident, enthusiastic person. This helps when you need to sell the product in to the retailers so they put this on their shelves
What's the main thing you would like to get from this mentoring?
I think just more insight into the work and nature of marketing and the environment as most people perceive it to be just selling items but it's much more than that.
It's a lot more than that, there is a lot of input and steps before the sales of the items which you need to complete before you can even get to that stage
I don't think I've asked but before you were a brand manager, what did your work include in marketing? (day to day) Was it the same as you're doing now?

At assistant brand manager level it was more data analysis and creating the artworks with agencies. Anything really that would support my manager. I would attend meetings with my manager but not lead them, I would attend the presentations and maybe present 4 or 5 slides
A lot more hands off but getting you ready for the brand management level

As part of my media coursework, I have to research into mental health and other social issues and create a social issue print campaign. These are all my own ideas based on my research. This may be a stretch, but I am going to create my posters using photoshop in the form of a social issue campaign coming up with my own ideas of how to portray it. Could this be something I could use to show creativity skills>
